Class Menu

java.lang.Object
menu.Menu
All Implemented Interfaces:
Runnable
public class Menu extends Object implements Runnable
A simple multi-level console menu system using the Observer pattern.

Menu includes a public result field to collect text to be displayed below the menu. The Menu constructor specifies pre text to be displayed above the menu / result, post text to be displayed below the menu / result, and zero or more MenuItem objects that comprise the menu itself.

Each MenuItem object specifies the text for a menu entry and the Runnable object to invoke when that menu entry is selected. Menu uses the sequential non-negative integers for selecting a MenuItem.

The run() method provides a complete main loop for the application. Also available are the runOnce() method, which allows the user to select one menu item to be run, and run(java.lang.Integer) which runs the specified menu item directly.

Menu also provides a static getString(String, String, String) method to obtain text from the user, as well as similar static methods for each primitive type such as getInt(String, String, String). Default values and a cancel option are optionally supported.

Another pair of convience static methods are arrayToString(java.lang.String,java.lang.Object[],java.lang.Character) and listToString(java.lang.String,java.util.List,java.lang.Character) to convert arrays and lists into numbered or bullet-point formats. These complement (for example) Arrays.toString(Object[]) by adding a vertical format to the existing comma-separated inside [ ] horizontal format.

In addition, Menu provides static selectItemFromArray(java.lang.String,java.lang.Object[]), selectItemFromList(java.lang.String,java.util.List), and selectFile(java.lang.String,java.io.File,java.io.FilenameFilter) methods for selecting one element from an array, List, or the filesystem.

Setting up and operating a menu is straightforward.

  1. In the constructor for the main class, instance a new menu, including the pre text (shown before the menu and result, often the title) and post text (shown after the menu and result, often data and a prompt), along with as many menu items as desired in the constructor and (if needed) via calls to the addMenuItem(menu.MenuItem) method.
  2. Invoke menu.run() to initiate the main loop. To exit via a MenuItem.run() callback, simply set result to null.
  3. Your main method need only construct the main class to execute the app.

A simple example application that collects and deletes strings is shown in full below. 

package demo;

import java.util.List;
import java.util.Arraylist;

import menu.Menu;
import menu.MenuItem;

public class DemoMenu {
    public DemoMenu() {
        String clearScreen = "\n".repeat(80);  // Scroll all text off display
        String title = "Demo Menu";            // The title of the menu
        title += '\n' + "=".repeat(title.length()) + '\n'; // Add underline
        menu = new Menu(
          new Object[] {clearScreen, title},   // pre  - print above menu / result
          new Object[] {this, "\nSelection?"}, // post - print below menu / result
          new MenuItem("Exit\n",        () -> endApp()),
          new MenuItem("Enter String",  () -> enterString()), // lambda
          new MenuItem("Remove String", this::removeString)   // method ref
        );
        menu.run(); // Start the main loop
    }
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        new DemoMenu(); // Run this application's main loop
    }
    public void endApp() {
        menu.result = null; // signal end of main loop
    }
    public void enterString() {
        String s = Menu.getString("Enter a String: ");
        if(s != null) strings.add(s);
    }
    public void removeString() {
        Integer index = Menu.selectItemFromList("Remove which string? ", strings);
        if(index != null) // null indicates cancel by default
            menu.result.append("\nRemoved \"" + strings.remove(index.intValue()) + '"');
    }

    // Called by "this" (in the 2nd constructor parameter above) to display our data.
    // The title is first, then the List, and finally the bullet to precede each element.
    // If the bullet were null, then each element's index would be the "bullet".
    @Override
    public String toString() {  
        return Menu.listToString("List of Strings\n---------------\n", strings, 'â€¢');
    }

    private List<String> strings = new ArrayList<>(); // the data
    private Menu menu;                                // the main menu
}

  • Field Details

    • result

      public StringBuilder result
      This field collects text to display below the menu text. The result object is null and ignored by default. If set non-null by application code, it will be cleared prior to each call to runOnce() and then printed below the menu. If set to null, run() will exit.
      Since:
      1.2

    • pre

      protected Object pre
      Array, Iterable, null, or plain old Java object to print before items.
      Since:
      1.2

    • items

      protected List<MenuItem> items
      Dispatch table of menu items.
      Since:
      1.0

    • post

      protected Object post
      Array, Iterable, null, or plain old Java object to print after items.
      Since:
      1.2

  • Constructor Details

    • Menu

      public Menu()
      Constructs a menu with no predefined text or menu items.
      Since:
      1.0

    • Menu

      public Menu(Object pre, Object post, MenuItem... items)
      Constructs a menu with specified pre and post text and optionalmenu items.

      The pre and post parameters may be a plain old Java object (pojo), an array, or an instance of Iterable such as a List. If an array or instance of iterable, they will be recursively traversed until a pojo (plain ole Java object) is found. Each pojo is printed as encountered prior to (for pre) or immediately following (for post) the menu text from the menu items and result.

      Unlike most other Java objects, String objects provided within pre or post will not reflect changes, since String is immutable. To change the text of a pre or post String object, use a StringBuilder object instead.

      Even if pre-populated, additional menu items may be added using addMenuItem(menu.MenuItem).

      Parameters:
      pre - Object(s) to print before the menu items, often a title.
      post - Object(s) to print after the menu items, often a prompt.
      items - Zero or more MenuItem instances to pre-populate the menu.
      Since:
      1.2

  • Method Details

    • addMenuItem

      public void addMenuItem(MenuItem item)
      Add a menu item to this menu at the next available integer index.
      Parameters:
      item - The menu item to be added.
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if item is null.
      Since:
      1.0

    • run

      public void run(Integer itemNumber)
      Invokes the selected item number.

      The itemNumber parameter is used to select a MenuItem object from the list added by Menu(java.lang.Object,java.lang.Object,menu.MenuItem...) and via the addMenuItem(menu.MenuItem) method. Then the selected Menutem object's run() method is called.

      If the item number is null, it is ignored.

      Parameters:
      itemNumber - The index of the MenuItem object to invoke.
      Since:
      1.0

    • runOnce

      public void runOnce()
      Display the menu, get selection, clear result, then execute selection.

      This is a convenience function that behaves as if for an instance of Menu named menu: 

      Integer command = Menu.getInt(menu.toString())); // Get user selection
if(result != null) result.setLength(0);          // Clear result
menu.run(command);                               // Call associated method
      Since:
      1.2

    • run

      public void run()
      Call runOnce() repeatedly until result becomes null.

      This is a convenience function that behaves as a main loop. It repeatedly calls runOnce(), which prints the menu and runs the selected observer. The main loop may be exited by setting result to null.

      Specified by:
      run in interface Runnable
      Since:
      1.2

    • toString

      public String toString()
      Converts the object to a fully formatted menu.

      The resulting string will be the string representation of pre, each element of items with the index as a selector, result, and the string representation of post.

      If pre or post is an array or Iterable, it will be recursively evaluated down to a sequence of plain old Java objects that will be appended in order to the resulting String.

      Elements that are null will be silently ignored.

      Thus, pre and post may represent a series of nested objects that comprise (for example) the title and the prompt of the final formatted menu returned by this method.

      Overrides:
      toString in class Object
      Since:
      1.0

    • getString

      public static String getString(String prompt, String cancelInput, String defaultInput)
      Prints the prompt and returns a trimmed String from the user.

      The prompt is printed exactly as provided, and a newline-terminated String from the user is read as input from the console.

      All whitespace is trimmed from the beginning and ending of the input. Then, if the String is empty and the defaultInput parameter is not null, input is replaced with the defaultInput parameter.

      If an exception occurs while reading and processing the input String, "Invalid input!" is printed and another attempt to read a String is made. Finally, if cancelInput is not null and matches the input, then null is returned. Otherwise, the input is returned.

      Parameters:
      prompt - The String to be printed (if not null) to prompt the user.
      cancelInput - The String that, if entered by the user, returns a null.
      defaultInput - The String that is returned if the user just presses Enter.
      Returns:
      null if the input matches cancelInput or the input String otherwise.
      Since:
      1.0

    • getString

      public static String getString(String prompt, String cancelInput)
      Prints the prompt and returns a trimmed String from the user.

      The prompt is printed exactly as provided, and a newline-terminated String from the user is read as input from the console.

      If an exception occurs while reading and processing the input String, "Invalid input!" is printed and another attempt to read a String is made.

      Finally, if cancelInput is not null and matches the input, then null is returned. Otherwise, the input is returned.

      Parameters:

      cancelInput - The String that, if entered by the user, returns a null.
      Returns:
      null if the input matches cancelInput or the input String otherwise.
      Since:
      1.0

    • getString

      Otherwise, the input is returned.

    • getInt

      public static Integer getInt(String prompt, String cancelInput, String defaultInput)
      Prints the prompt and returns an Integer from the user.

      The prompt is printed exactly as provided, and a newline-terminated String from the user is read as input from the console.

      All whitespace is trimmed from the beginning and ending of the input. Then, if the String is empty and the defaultInput parameter is not null, input is replaced with the defaultInput parameter.

      If the input matches cancelInput or is still empty, null is returned. Otherwise, the input is converted to an Integer and returned.

      If an exception occurs while reading and processing the input String and converting it to an Integer, "Invalid input!" is printed and another attempt to read a String is made.

      Parameters:
      prompt - The String to be printed (if not null) to prompt the user.
      cancelInput - The String that, if entered by the user, returns a null.
      defaultInput - The String converted to Integer if the user just presses Enter.
      Returns:
      null if the input matches cancelInput or the input Integer otherwise.
      Since:
      1.0

    • arrayToString

      public static String arrayToString(String title, Object[] array, Character bullet)
      Converts the array to a String preceded by the title (if not null).

      The title (if not null) precedes the array contents.

      Each element of the array is added, one per line, preceded by either bullet or (if bullet is null) its index and "] ". (The most common bullet is 'â€¢'.) So the following code: 

      String title = "The Three Stooges\n=== ===== =======\n\n";
String[] stooges = {"Larry", "Curly", "Moe"};
arrayToString(title, stooges, null);
      would result in "The Three Stooges\n=== ===== =======\n\n0] Larry\n1] Curly\n2] Moe".
      Parameters:
      title - The String to precede the array (ignored if null).
      array - The array to be converted to a String.
      bullet - Character to precede each element, or use the index if null
      Returns:
      The String representation of the array in list form.
      Since:
      1.3

    • listToString

      public static String listToString(String title, List list, Character bullet)
      Converts the List to a String preceded by the title (if not null).

      The title (if not null) precedes the List contents.

      Each element of the list is added, one per line, preceded by either bullet or (if bullet is null) its index and "] ". (The most common bullet is 'â€¢'.) So the following code: 

      String title = "The Three Stooges\n=== ===== =======\n\n";
List<String> stooges = new ArrayList<>(); 
stooges.add("Larry");
stooges.add("Curly"; 
stooges.add("Moe");
System.out.println(listToString(title, stooges, null));
      would result in "The Three Stooges\n=== ===== =======\n\n0] Larry\n1] Curly\n2] Moe".
      Parameters:
      title - The String to precede the array (ignored if null).
      list - The List to be converted to a String.
      bullet - Character to precede each element, or use the index if null
      Returns:
      The String representation of the array in list form.
      Since:
      1.3

    • selectItemFromArray

      public static Integer selectItemFromArray(String prompt, Object[] array, String cancelInput, String defaultInput)
      Prints the prompt and array, allowing the user to select an array element.

      If the array is null or of zero length, null is returned. If the array contains a single object, 0 is returned.

      Otherwise, the prompt is printed exactly as provided, along with a menu showing indices and toString representations of the array elements. A newline-terminated String from the user is read as input from the console.

      All whitespace is trimmed from the beginning and ending of the input. Then, if the String is empty and the defaultInd parameter is not null, input is replaced with the defaultInput parameter.

      If the input matches cancelInput or is still empty, null is returned. Otherwise, the input is converted to an Integer and returned.

      If an exception occurs while reading and processing the input String and converting it to an Integer, "Invalid input!" is printed and another attempt to read a String is made.

      Parameters:
      prompt - The String to be printed (if not null) to prompt the user.
      array - The array of objects from which the user will select.
      cancelInput - The String that, if entered by the user, returns a null.
      defaultInput - The String converted to an Integer if the user presses Enter.
      Returns:
      null if the input matches cancelInput or the input Integer otherwise.
      Since:
      1.1

    • selectItemFromArray

      public static Integer selectItemFromArray(String prompt, Object[] array, String cancelInput)
      Prints the prompt and array, allowing the user to select an array element.

      If an exception occurs while reading and processing the input String and converting it to an Integer, "Invalid input!" is printed and another attempt to read a String is made.

      Parameters:

      array - The array of objects from which the user will select.
      cancelInput - The String that, if entered by the user, returns a null.

    • selectFile

      public static File selectFile(String prompt, File starting, FilenameFilter filter)
      Navigates the filesystem so the user can select or create a file or directory.

      The subdirectories (with a trailing '/') and files in the starting directory that match filter are listed in case-insensitive sort order along with 4 additional options: 

      (0) .. changes to the parent directory
(1) .  returns a File object for the current folder
(2) +  prompts for a new subdirectory path, and creates and changes to it
(3) ++ prompts for a new filename and returns a File object for it

      Otherwise, if a subdirectory is selected it is opened and the method repeats. If a file or a directory is selected it is returned. If the user enters a negative selection, null is returned to signal that the user declined to select a file or directory. If the user enters a positive but out of bounds index, an error message is displayed followed by the prompt.

      The directory from which the program was launched may be selected for starting by setting the second parameter to 

      new File(System.getProperty("user.dir"))
      .
      Parameters:
      prompt - Requests input from the user, or no prompt if null
      starting - The first directory to be listed, or user.home if null
      filter - Files to show or show all non-hidden files if null
      Returns:
      The selected File object, or null if no file was selected

    • equals

      public boolean equals(Object o)
      Compares the specified object with this menu for equality. Returns true if and only if the specified object is also a Menu and the pre, items, and post fields are equal.
      Overrides:
      equals in class Object
      Parameters:
      o - the object to be compared for equality with this Menu
      Returns:
      true if the specified object is equal to this Menu
      Since:
      1.3

    • hashCode

      public int hashCode()
      Returns the hash code value for this Menu. The pre, items, and post fields are significant to the hashCode.
      Overrides:
      hashCode in class Object
      Returns:
      the hash code value for this Menu
      Since:
      1.3
